newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: FORECAST-FCL Forest year profit to fall.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-FCL Forest year profit to fall.

text.p: Abysmal log prices and other factors are likely to combine to drag Fletcher Challenge Forest Division's earnings down to around NZ$65 million in the year to June against $68 million a year ago, analysts said on Friday.
But the market will not be too concerned.
Forest has been riding the crest of a wave after successfully bidding, along with Brierley Investments Ltd and China's Citic, for Forestry Corp of NZ on Tuesday.
The stock has been powering ahead since the sale announcement, and closed on Friday at NZ$2.03, up nine cents.
The move almost doubles Forest's estate to around 300,000 hectares.
"I don't think people care about the result because they are focusing far more on the implications of the acquisition of Forestry Corp," David Stanley at Doyle Paterson Brown said.
Analysts have been impressed by the synergistic benefits from the deal.
Forest itself had been assisted by the price the consortium was prepared to pay -- NZ$2.026 billion -- in that it improves the valuation of Forest's existing estate.

"In terms of the result, it will be pretty awful," Stanley said. "Log prices have been falling this year, the currency has gone up, and basically this is a U.S. dollar-denominated business based in New Zealand. What that's meant is revenues have gone down quite quickly."
Stanley expects the company's earnings to come in at NZ$58 million before abnormals.
Denis Lee at Hendry Hay McItonsh said he expected a number around NZ$60 million, but he too was optimstic for the future.
"There will be a positive impact on earnings (from the Forestry Corp purchase). The extent of that is yet to be seen."
